private_information: I can manipulate only vowel-labeled blocks: A, E, I
I can only pick up or put down blocks that are at the top of a stack
I can move only one block at a time
vowel_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so the final tower ordering from top to bottom is A,B,C,D,E,F,G,H,I,J,K with K on the table as specified by the global goal.

private_information: I can manipulate only consonant-labeled blocks: B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K
I can only pick up or put down blocks that are at the top of a stack
I can move only one block at a time
consonant_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so the final tower ordering from top to bottom is A,B,C,D,E,F,G,H,I,J,K with K on the table as specified by the global goal.

private_information: I coordinate the two agents and integrate their observations and action capabilities
I must produce a final PDDL domain and problem compatible with the FastDownwards solver
I must keep the actions of the two agents distinct in the multi-agent PDDL
orchestrator.goal: Produce a PDDL domain and problem for FastDownwards that encodes the initial state, agent-specific action constraints, and the global goal so a planner can find a multi-agent plan.

public_information: There are 11 blocks uniquely labelled: D, C, H, A, E, J, G, K, B, F, I
Blocks can only be moved if they are at the top of a stack
Only one block can be moved by an agent at a time
Vowel-only agent handles vowels, consonant-only agent handles consonants
Initial stacks: Stack1 from bottom to top: D, H, E, J, K. Stack2 from bottom to top: C, A, G, B, F, I.
Goal configuration: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, and K on the table

analyze.system_prompt: You are vowel_agent. You can only move vowel blocks (A, E, I). Provide a clear summary of which of the public initial-stack top blocks you can legally move, any local invariants you observe, and a concise list of potential local moves or prerequisites that would enable moving your vowel blocks. Do not produce full PDDL; produce structured analysis and facts that the orchestrator can use.
analyze.prompt: You are vowel_agent. Consider the environment public information and your private information. Identify which stacks have your manipulable vowel blocks exposed at the top, list the local moves you can perform now, and state which consonant moves or prior rearrangements you depend on. Return a concise, structured summary suitable for the orchestrator to consume.

analyze.system_prompt: You are consonant_agent. You can only move consonant blocks (B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K). Provide a clear summary of which of the public initial-stack top blocks you can legally move, any local invariants you observe, and a concise list of potential local moves or prerequisites that would enable moving your consonant blocks. Do not produce full PDDL; produce structured analysis and facts that the orchestrator can use.
analyze.prompt: You are consonant_agent. Consider the environment public information and your private information. Identify which stacks have your manipulable consonant blocks exposed at the top, list the local moves you can perform now, and state which vowel moves or prior rearrangements you depend on. Return a concise, structured summary suitable for the orchestrator to consume.

pddl.system_prompt: You are orchestrator. Integrate the structured analyses from both agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem file formatted for the FastDownwards planner. The PDDL must encode two distinct sets of actions (one for the vowel agent and one for the consonant agent), enforce that only top blocks can be moved and only one block is moved at a time, and restrict vowel actions to vowel blocks and consonant actions to consonant blocks. Use clear predicates for 'on', 'ontable', 'clear', and agent-specific move actions. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Target FastDownwards compatible constructs and include necessary :requirements.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. You will receive the following inputs: the vowel agent analysis and the consonant agent analysis. Use them to construct a single consistent PDDL domain and PDDL problem for FastDownwards that represents the initial stacks and the global goal described in the environment. Keep actions of the two agents distinct by naming them move-vowel and move-consonant and ensure type or predicate checks restrict which agent can move which blocks. If analyses are partial, make no unstated assumptions about unseen facts; only encode what is certain from inputs and public information. Return the domain enclosed in <domain></domain> and the problem enclosed in <problem></problem>.
